specs/train/atomic-extraroute.rst.message: From discussion at the PTG: another problem is that routes are identified only by their data (destination/nexthop/router id); there's no way to uniquely identify the source of a route. So if two things add the same route then if one is deleted then the other will be broken (or alternatively, we could fail if two Heat stacks try to create the same route, but that's also bad and doesn't prevent other tools from doing the same).
I did raise this problem in the Neutron PTG. And added a proposal addressing this to the Neutron spec.
This changed in the new proposal to extraroute-firstclass.

Experience with SoftwareDeployments is that this leads to massive confusion where you always have to clarify whether you're talking about a series of ExtraRoute resources vs. a single ExtraRoutes resource. Something like ExtraRouteList might be better.
I think I will change this to OS::Neutron::ExtraRouteSet.

This is probably a good idea, because it allows users to use e.g. the repeat function or just passing data from parameters to create a variable number of routes.

However, it's very difficult for Heat to store a *list* of UUIDs as the physical ID of a resource. So if we're assigning a UUID to deal with the idempotency problem identified above, then we can really only do this if we have a single UUID for the group.

In other words, we can only do it this way if the Neutron API also supports a *group* of extra routes as the resource identified by a UUID.

In order to keep the neutron api relatively simple I did remove the option of multi-update in ps5 of the neutron spec. I'll come back to the question of ExtraRoute or ExtraRouteSet when the neutron api is finalized.

nova/virt/libvirt/driver.py.message:
We might need some defaults for hw_rng:rate_bytes and hw_rng:rate_period.I'm not sure what 0 means.

Or maybe configuration options to control the default behavior?

0 means "Don't add rate limit", see below:
...
if rate_bytes:

I think, configuration option would be useful, if we wanted to preserve original behaviour or set it like it was before by default. I'm not sure if original behaviour is desirable by anyone.

So, why would someone *not* want this enabled? With this change, the semantics of the 'hw_rng:allowed' extra spec change. Previously, it had to be explicitly set to a truey value to do something (enable the thing) while now it would have to be explicitly set to a falsey value to something (disable the thing). This needs a reno, for a start, but does raise the question of whether we actually need this extra spec now.

On a similar but perhaps even more pressing note, the 'hw_rng_model' image metadata property is now totally useless with this change. We should document it as such and leave a TODO on the corresponding field of the ImageMetaProps object to remind us to remove it in a future version bump. We should also update the docs here and in glance to note its new uselessness.

Whoops, I don't think we should remove the 'hw_rng_model' property.  When I wrote the above I didn't bear in mind that from libvirt 5.2.0 onwards, it now allows "VirtIO transitional / non-transitional devices"[1]—to choose whether you want to have compatibility with older guest operating systems, which in turn will decide the PCI topology.  With that the  possible values for 'hw_rng_model' will be:

* virtio
* virtio-transitional (since libvirt 5.2.0)
* virtio-non-transitional (since libvirt 5.2.0)

[1]  https://libvirt.org/formatdomain.html#elementsVirtioTransitional

I can't think of a reason why someone does _not_ want an RNG device by default; I was trying to be cautious.  I'd say we can unconditionally add the VirtIO-RNG device.

On change of semantics for 'hw_rng:allowed': yes, needs a reno.  And I'll wait for any other views before we consider dropping the extra spec altogether.

On 'hw_rng_model': yes, good reminders on documentation across the board (and eventual removal).

this is not the negation of the original condition. that would be 

    not rng_is_virtio or not rng_allowed

So in the baseline we only added the device if 'hw_rng_model' was 'virtio' and the 'hw_rng:allowed' was True. But now if the 'hw_rng:allowed' is True but the 'hw_rng_model' is non virtio then we go ahead and add the device.

Yes, the actual negation would be 'or'.  However, we _do_ need the 'and' here.  (The `hw_rng_model` property will have no effect _unless_ `hw_rng:allowed` is 'True'.)  Also 'hw_rng_model' allows only 'virtio' currently: https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/824bc358c25564ed6603d8f94587abd8902fe5af/nova/objects/fields.py#L481-L486

specs/ussuri/mistral-to-ansible.rst.message: We've had a few more people join in on this. Kevin, Sagi, and I. (Once I'm done with scale testing, I'm coming 100% back to this Mistral conversion work).

Does this include the workflows which derive parameters [1]?

I'm not opposed to replacing Mistral with Ansible (I think this proposal will make TripleO more user friendly) but I want to see what the plan is for this feature. Do we need an accompanying blueprint or spec?

The derive parameters feature updated THT params in the deployment plan before they got to puppet. Given the way config-download works with external-deloy steps we already have a translation layer from THT to Ansible [2] so I see a possible opening there to add some derivation during the translation. I'm not sure how this will work with the Nova parameters the HCI derivation needs to change however.

Adding Saravanan, Jaganathan, and Alan who worked on derived params.

[1] https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/tripleo-specs/specs/pike/tripleo-derive-parameters.html

[2] https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-ansible/src/branch/master/tripleo_ansible/roles/tripleo-ceph-work-dir/tasks/prepare.yml#L41-L44

> I don't know about dervice parameters yet. This is something that

 > that workflow. The workload is huge so we are just taking the
 > workflows one at a time for now.

So it's possible then that this workflow isn't replaced during the U cycle? E.g. you might get a majority of the workflows converted as described here during U but Mistral may not be removed until V?

IMO, Ealier the whole derive params feature was relying on the stack preview output and the introspection data to provide the heat output parameters. And the long-term target is to remove heat in tripleo deployment tools. 

Paraemters could be derived on each node and applied to the ansible facts (and in turn to the hiera data, till puppet is around). It should be done before the step 0 of deploy steps for DPDK (it might need additional inputs like nic configs, to identify DPDK interfaces, which is already availble in config-download process). 

There is already a tool developed with the focus of newton (since derived parameters was introduced in pike) to help with the deployments. 
https://github.com/redhat-nfvpe/python-tripleo-derive-params

We could create filters and libraries out of this repo in to tripleo-ansible repo. And we need to add HCI too. There is no hard dependecy on YAQL, it could be acheived with ansible (and python).

@Saravanan, agree but can we add the python scripts in tripleo-heat-templates instead of adding in tripleo-ansible repo because we may need to update python scripts if any formula's to be customized like updating workbooks in undercloud.

yes, the short answer is that it includes all workflows. If we leave any then we will be unable to remove Mistral which somewhat defeats the goal.

I don't have anything of substance to add to what John has already noted, though I'm curious how the dervied parameters workflows will be migrated. The workflows are essentially a series of complex yaql expressions.

lower-constraints.txt.message: we cannot drop six from lower-constraints.txt now as at least oslo.utils still uses six.

n my understanding, we need to cover nested dependencies in our lower-constraints.txt. lower-constraints cannot be inherited. If we don't cover nested libraries (six from oslo.utils in this case) in our l-c, the latest release of a library. This potentially causes a breakage by a change in a nested library or using a latest nested library (which usually happens after stable branches are cut). 
If you need a wide consensus, I can send a mail to openstack-discuss.

Of course you can send a mail and thanks for this.

But as I commented, if we need to limit a lower version we should limit the directly imported library version; in this case, oslo.utils.

BTW, lower oslo.utils version (3.30.0), limits six to >=1.10.0.

But any library should take care of its own imports. In this case, oslo.utils requires at least 1.10.0 [1].

If this project is not using a library, it can't enforce the version of a nested one (there could be some exceptions).

[1] https://github.com/openstack/oslo.utils/blob/master/lower-constraints.txt#L38

Okay, I will send a mail to the mailing to confirm what is the right solution. It looks like we have opposite opinons on what libraries should be covered in lower-constraints.txt. I believe we need to cover six in l-c at the current situation, so I just +1 to this patch. Feel free to +2/W if other reviewers believe it should be dropped from l-c.
technically you don't need to do this, just updating requirements.txt - there's a lot of libraries here neutron-lib doesn't use
Yes, but because we are not using this library anymore, there is no reason to set a limit in this project for a library not needed/used.

In my first drafts of https://review.opendev.org/#/c/698602/ I proposed to instantiate a LocalClient or a RemoteClient (depending on your needs and on the given params but Federico prefered to managed connection through an SSH tunnel rather than managing the SSH connection by using a RemoteClient. The Federico's comments [2] related to this topic make sense [2][3].

I'm not aware of all the mechanismes under the hood in tobiko to manage podman connection through an SSH tunnel and also I'm not a docker-py [4] expert but docker-py and varlink seems to work in the same way concerning `base_url` and `uri` so if tobiko can is capable to create a local TCP port I don't think we need to do that and we could continue with the the previous version of this code, apparently if I understand it correctly tobiko can work like this so this is why I chose to always use a podman LocalClient by not using the `remote_uri` param.

~/tobiko/test/lib/python3.6/site-packages/podman/client.py in factory(cls, uri, interface, *args, **kwargs)
     55         local_path = urlparse(uri).path
     56         if local_path == '':
---> 57             raise ValueError('path is required for uri,'
     58                              ' expected format "unix://path_to_socket"')

I believe we should use podman.client's native way of client creation rather than making it integrate with tobiko's client creation method.

In the case that we decide to continue with a `RemoteClient` then for the sake of lisibility it can be worth to use named variables:

```
remote_uri = 'ssh://{username}@{host}{socket}'.format(
    username=self.ssh_client.connect_parameters['username'],
    host=self.ssh_client.host,
    socket=podman_remote_socket)
```

Here I think we need to keep `podman_remote_socket` content rather than a hard coded value.

The `self.discover_podman_socket()` calling will call the podman `_shell.discover_podman_socket` by passing the ssh client [1] as param so you will get the result from your ssh host [2]

We are talking about stable branches, so it sounds a bit aggressive wording to me. I think a minor version bump is required when we have a change which is not just a simple bug fix. [2] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/667124/
[3] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/424224/

In my terms the third part of the version ID is called "patch number". Also, that release would then be called a patch release and not a minor release.

Also maybe add a comment that such type of changes (requiring a minor version step) always needs to be accompanied by a release note.

Yeah, we use 'patch number' in the semantic versioning.
https://semver.org/

reference/runtimes/victoria.rst.message:
Note that CentOS 8 and openSUSE Leap 15 are both python 3.6 platforms and Ubuntu 20.04 is scheduled to have python3.8.

From a practical standpoint that may make testing python3.7 directly difficult. However, testing that we run on 3.6 and 3.8 likely means 3.7 will function as a side effect.

If none of our official platforms has 3.7 as the default, I think we can drop it and just declare 3.6 and 3.8 as supported. It's a little odd, but I would assume testing under 3.6 and 3.8 would be sufficient for anyone that does actually want to use 3.7 unofficially.

Ah yep, I misread. So it is 3.6.

We should probably change 15 to 15.1. And CentOS 8 to CentOS 8.0 (it's entirely possible that versions of Python will change in minor releases of CentOS 8).

But, a reminder of our process: https://governance.openstack.org/tc/resolutions/20181024-python-update-process.html

The selected versions are not only the default ones in these distros, but also "Each Python 3 version that was still used in any integration tests at the beginning of the development cycle." Integration tests are currently on Bionic, and we have no plans to move to Focal during Ussuri, so we need 3.7 for now. We can drop the 3.7 requirement as soon as we've migrated integration tests to Focal (which can be during the Victoria cycle).

There are two openSUSE distros currently in the supported list: openSUSE Leap 15.x (which will stay for the foreseeable future on python 3.6) and openSUSE Tumblweed (which is just switching to python 3.8). 

So python 3.6 and 3.8 are the only ones needed from SUSE perspective. there is no need for 3.7

AFAIK Leap 15.1 ships with py3.6 as of today. It's indeed the current version. The next release, 15.2, out around May 2020 (IIRC), would be still 3.6. Tumbleweed (rolling distro) uses 3.7 right now, and is not yet ready for 3.8.

However, developers that might want to use 3.8 might add the appropriate Factory repository (experiemental).

For SUSE, I would say that 3.6 and 3.8 would be enough, as I am not sure anyone here is ready to maintain tumbleweed in gates in the sole purpose of testing py3.7, if we already have 3.6 and 3.8.

Dirk, would you agree with that?

Both LEAP 15.0 and 15.1 currently support both Python 2 and Python 3. The official statement is that we support Python 3 - which is incredibly vague. Looking through the supported packages, we only support up to 3.6, NOT 3.7.

The SLE number versioning basically went 12 and then skipped to 15. From here, we've had 15 and then 15.1, and we're looking at going to 15.2. I'm not sure what light there is to shed there other than "that's the numbering system, enjoy". I believe you are correct, 15.1 was current for Ussuri.
That sounds fair and okay for me. We'll update the runtimes by then.

IIUC Leap 15.1 has Python 3.7. IIUC that's also the current version number of the LTS release. (Perhaps we should update line 13, although I think that 15.1 was current for Ussuri and we just said 15 for that. TBH I'm not clear on how version numbering of OpenSUSE works these days.) Maybe JP can shed some more light.

This may become challenging for the W cycle as Python 3.9 is slated to release shortly before that cycle will probably start (PEP 596 estimates 2020-10-05), and the platforms we're testing on might not carry it straight away. That said, it all depends on how you define "available" in this context, and we should likely just address that discrepancy when the time comes anyway.

We define it as "The latest released version of Python 3 that is available in any distribution we can feasibly use for testing." I didn't copy the whole definition in here because it's available in the link.

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
If this is "test only" issue, is there maybe any other possible solution to fix that in fullstack tests and not change production code just because of tests?

How it can happend that some other QoS references to the same Queue?
For example in test which failed like that in bug report, there was only one agent spawned: https://storage.gra1.cloud.ovh.net/v1/AUTH_dcaab5e32b234d56b626f72581e3644c/zuul_opendev_logs_847/681893/1/gate/neutron-fullstack/847f4d9/controller/logs/dsvm-fullstack-logs/TestMinBwQoSOvs.test_bw_limit_qos_port_removed_egress_/

I know that there are other tests running and spawning ovs agents in parallel but neutron-ovs agent is looking for QoS and Queues always using port_name and port_name is based on uuid. Do You think we could have same port names for more than one port?
Maybe we than should add "bridge_name" to https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/master/neutron/agent/common/ovs_lib.py#L715 and https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/master/neutron/agent/common/ovs_lib.py#L723 and to places where we are creating those queues and qos?

Actually you are right. The problem we are seeing here is that in [1] (the tests case with the error), we are detecting a port created in [2], in particular port e94ef7d2-82e8-43cf-8978-6b9ba8e9ad3f. In [2], this port is created and a Queue is assigned (a1470780-1834-48d9-afd0-6fe41fcbb027) with min-rate 300000.

When test [1] receives the notification of a new port (created in [2]), it tries to delete it:
- Find the agent QoS: this is unique (should be unique), based on
    OVSBridge._min_bw_qos_id = uuidutils.generate_uuid()
- Find the Queue, based on the port ID. In this case, this Queue is NOT in this QoS. When the QoS register is deleted, the Queue is still attached to the QoS register created in [2], with another _id = _min_bw_qos_id.

Here is when we have the referential integrity violation exception.

This is happening only in tests but this could be solved by adding/deleting the QoS rule information in QosOVSAgentDriver.port, the same as in:
- delete_bandwidth_limit
- delete_bandwidth_limit_ingress
- delete_dscp_marking


[1] https://storage.gra1.cloud.ovh.net/v1/AUTH_dcaab5e32b234d56b626f72581e3644c/zuul_opendev_logs_847/681893/1/gate/neutron-fullstack/847f4d9/controller/logs/dsvm-fullstack-logs/TestMinBwQoSOvs.test_bw_limit_qos_port_removed_egress_/neutron-openvswitch-agent--2019-09-17--05-35-29-575569_log.txt.gz
[2] https://storage.gra1.cloud.ovh.net/v1/AUTH_dcaab5e32b234d56b626f72581e3644c/zuul_opendev_logs_847/681893/1/gate/neutron-fullstack/847f4d9/controller/logs/dsvm-fullstack-logs/TestMinBwQoSOvs.test_min_bw_qos_policy_rule_lifecycle_egress_/neutron-openvswitch-agent--2019-09-17--05-35-33-485208_log.txt.gz

No other agent/process should use this Queue. This Queue is created specifically by the OVS agent and only to shape the traffic of those ports with the same QoS policy and rule. This should never happen in a real environment. In this case, of course something will be broken but because other process is managing something does not own.

m = re.search(r"ovs-vsctl.*(\d+\.\d+)", out, re.M)

tobiko/tests/faults/ha/cloud_disruptions.message: SSH client operations already have timeout functionality. We don't need to reimplement it.

I couldn't find how the time out is implemented in the ssh_client (where is it ? ) , also,  I need to retry connectivity here (even though the remote host is unreachable).. does the ssh_client timeout provide that ?
Tobiko topology nodes have an attribute called ssh_client. We don't need to call this function to have access to them.

Please use higher level tobiko sh.execute instead of this one:

  from tobiko.shell impot sh
  sh.execute("whoami")

The function is higher level and we could put there logic to remake SSH connection when we lose it.

despite the name if client is already connecteded, connect function return the same connected client. To reconnect the node we have to reset the ssh client fixture:

  tobiko.reset(node_ssh_client)

above is the same as writing:
 
 tobiko.cleanup(node_ssh_client)
 tobiko.setup(node_ssh_client)
Just leave the simplest implementation based on SSH client for now. If we can do it without spawning ansible as os faults does, it is better (faster, simpler and cheaper).

from tobiko.shell import sh

sh.execute('sudo reboot', ssh_client=controller.ssh_client)

A function that reboot a list of nodew should use and pass the SSH client as parameter, not node name.

I thing below code should work:

 def reboot_nodes(nodes):
     # reset all nodes
     for node in nodes:
          sh.execute('sudo reboot', ssh_client=node.ssh_client)
          # actively close SSH connection
          tobiko.cleanup(node.ssh_client)

     # wait for node connectivity
     for node in nodes:
          sh.execute('hostname', ssh_client=node.ssh_client)
          yield node  # the node client is now available an working
I would remove the last line that yields nodes. I don't think it is required.
My updated code does the same I think , and wraps the reconnect ssh in a try-except clause , so I will test this ...

roles/build-wheels/files/wheel-build.sh.message: After discussion in IRC, it sounds like what you're saying is that if CFLAGS is defined in the environment calling this script (for example to set -O2 optimization level) then this will clobber it, but this seems unlikely (and if it is a real concern, we can change this to export CFLAGS="$CFLAGS -g0" instead). Exporting CFLAGS in this script should at least be additive with any sanely-constructed build toolchains which should append them to any baked-in compiler flags set in, say, a Makefile for the C extension. If they don't, that's a bug we should raise upstream with their respective maintainers.

I meant using CFLAGS="$CFLAGS -g0" if the concern is that we're clobbering any CFLAGS value which was set in the environment which called this script, but I'm honestly still not sure what you're trying to say. Is the concern that some build toolchains may only add optimization options to the cc CLI if CFLAGS is *not* already set in the environment which calls them?
that means no optimization, why not add "-O2" as well?

export CFLAGS="$CFLAGS -g0" will not work here, since we set CFLAGS here - and then call the build job.

If this overrides CFLAGS in the package, I would use CFLAGS="-g0 -O2".

Looking at one package, it was working fine with that change.

I couldn't find any definite python packaging building instructions on what to use...
